text: cases, want elaborate visuals, may easier accomplish ggplot2 ordinary ggmaps. examples:

heading: 5.7.1 Scatterplot
text: Let us start basic plotting. Note ‚Äòlat‚Äô ‚Äòlon‚Äô expected names x y values.see two issues. First, legend inset top left. can modified within ggmap. Second, map colors may confusing, given parks water colors several categories. Let us correct issues:used arguments extent = ‚Äòdevice‚Äô legend = ‚Äútopleft‚Äù move legend, source = ‚Äòstamen‚Äô maptype = ‚Äútoner‚Äù adjust map‚Äôs appearance.
code:
wifi_data_renamed <- mutate(wifi_data, lat = Latitude, lon = Longitude)
nyc <- get_map(location = "manhattan", zoom = 12)
ggmap(nyc) +
  geom_point(data = wifi_data_renamed, aes(color = Type), alpha=.2)
nyc <- get_map(location = "manhattan", zoom = 12, source = 'stamen', maptype = "toner")
ggmap(nyc, extent = 'device', legend = "topleft") +
  geom_point(data = wifi_data_renamed, aes(color = Type), alpha=.2)

  geom_bin_2d(data = wifi_data_renamed, aes(color = Type, fill = Type), bins = 40, alpha=.7)

code:

heading: 5.7.4 Overlaying Routes
text: One neat feature ggmap ability superimpose routes. map shows available WiFi hotspots near walking route Columbia Central Park:
code:
to_cp <- route(from = 'Columbia University', to = 'Frederick Douglass Circle', mode = 'walking')
nyc <- get_map(location = c(-73.96, 40.803), zoom = 16, color = 'bw')
ggmap(nyc) +
  geom_leg(aes(x = start_lon, y = start_lat, xend = end_lon, yend = end_lat), size = 2, color = 'blue', data=to_cp) +
  geom_point(data = wifi_data_renamed, color = 'red')
